About the boat thing - it wouldn't "bob" because of the density change (the same weight is applied to the boat), but when the water drips out, between the time it's supported by your hand and the time it hits the boat floor (while it's losing potential energy) the boat isn't supporting its weight so it should bob up a minute amount ; on the other hand when it hits the boat floor, all that kinetic energy discharges and the boat should go down a minute amount, and finally now that the water drop is at rest on the boat, the boat supports the same amount of weight as before and should go back to its initial height. I'm neglecting the change in Archimedes' force in air because I feel like the tiny change in volume multiplied by the very low density of air at atmospheric pressure (compared to oil) isn't going to impact the result too much ; but I guess if the measurement was precise enough, there would be a tiny drop in the boat's height, since liquid water is denser than ice and therefore displaces less air?

Alright.
Would water melting from your hand, dripping to the bottom of the boat, affect its buoyancy?
Yes. Marginally.
It's still the same mass of water, and as it's supported by the boat regardless of if it's in your hand or in the bottom of the boat.
BUT it's safe to assume that if it's dripping down from your hand to the bottom of the boat, it in its ice form was, in fact, elevated.
And the earth's gravity has less and less of an effect the farther away a mass is. Thus, the water in your hand would weigh fractionally less than when it was in the bottom of the boat.

No, the boat would not move. This is because the density of the items on a boat doesn’t matter, it is the mass that does. The mass of the objects aboard, and that make up, the boat has to be less than the mass of the water that the boat displaces, or moves. When an ice cube melts, the density changes, but the mass does not.

Edit: looking at other replies, the boat would bob up and down. This is because the water droplet would spend some amount of time in the air free falling, where it is not a part of the mass of the boat, causing the boat to rise. Once it hits the boat, it transfers the momentum to the boat, causing the boat to fall. The amount it rises and falls would be erased though, due to friction and other outside factors.

The boat displaces a volume of water with a mass equal to the mass contained within (including the boat).  However, there would be a (very) slight reduction of downward force and "contained" mass when the drop is released from the held cube, and then there would be a momentary (slight) impulse of force as the drop inelastically collides with the bottom of the boat, and then after some slight oscillations the system would settle to very nearly the same amount of water displaced and level as before.  I say very nearly, because the boat-ice system did lose some total mass-energy in that the drop of water is now at the bottom of the boat at reduced potential.  However, it did gain some thermal energy.  I'd have to run some numbers to determine if the gained thermal energy is less than or equal to the loss in gravitational potential energy.  In any case, these effects are incredibly negligible, but interesting to consider in an ideal, closed system.

Old physics question: You take your canoe to a lake. Before you put the canoe in the water, you add a rock. You get in, row out to the center, take a super accurate measurement of the water level in the lake. Then you toss in the rock. What happens to the water level: up, down, or no change? No change. The water level changed you added the canoe, yourself, and the rock to the lake. The rock is displacing water already. Tossing it in the lake will permanently change the water level, but from your vantage point, the level stays the same.

I'm not sure that the "hot ice" is freezing. It seems more likely to me that the sodium acetate is crystallising.

When you heat the sodium acetate solution, the solubility of sodium acetate is very high. When you cool the solution, though, you make a super-saturated solution : that is, you've exceeded the solubility of sodium acetate in water, but it cannot crystallise without a nucleus. When you introduce a nucleation site, the sodium acetate rapidly crystallises, releasing its lattice energy as heat.

You could test which is correct by filtering the "hot ice" to separate it from the water. Then, heat the "hot ice" by itself using a water bath (to limit the temperature to 100 °C). If the "hot ice" melts, then it probably is frozen sodium acetate solution. If it does not, then it was crystallised sodium acetate.

@3:32 Short answer, no with an explanation. Long answer, yes with a but.

Any of the changes due to the process of dropping water are small forces that have less "impact" than common forces such as those caused by waves and even ripples in the water. Very tight experimental control would be required to measure the changes.

First, the actual drip. Frozen water in the cube has a downward force transmitted through your body and into the boat. The boat displaces a mass of water equal to the mass of the cube, in addition to other water displaced. At the moment of the drip less force is transmitted through the body witch could cause a slight rise of the boat.

While in free fall, the drop will displace air molecules, which in turn displace other air molecules. As the force is transferred through the air, some force is lost to air motion and a slight temperature rise due to the mechanical work of moving the air. Some of that force transfers to the deck of the boat, causing it to go back down, but not as much as it rose initially. Very sensitive equipment is required to measure this change, and other movement in the air will mask these readings.

Next, the drop impacts the deck. This is an impulse force that pushed down on the boat. The dip caused by the impulse of the impact is determined by the mass of the drop, the velocity at the time of impact, and the viscosity, which affects the duration of the impact and the force transferred into the deck and the energy lost to changing the shape of the droplet. This pushes the boat downward, but only while the impact takes place.

Now, the droplet of water is on the deck. The boat, with some buoyant motion, returns to the original height. But the ripples from the changes may reflect back to the boat and prolong the time needed to reach equilibrium.

We also need to consider the environment. The cold ice, depending of the humidity of the air, will cause water to condense from the air and add to the mass of the water in the cube and on the deck. This would result in the final position of the boat being lower. However, depending of the thermal characteristics is the deck, it will take heat energy from the sun and air and raise the temperature of the water causing some to evaluate. This will result in the final position being higher.

Early on, condensation will win, but if we let the experiment go on long enough evaporation will win and no water will be left, leaving the boat higher.

Ice is less dense than water, so when the ice turns to water the water will take up a smaller volume but weigh the same. If the boat isn't a completely closed space, some extra air will take up that space so the overall weight in the boat will increase (by a teeny tiny amount). This should push the boat down in the water (again by a ridiculously small amount).

The slight change in density of the melting ice may change the amount of displaced air, creating a new equilibrium. I think this would lift the boat upwards an infinitesimal amount. But this would be negligible even for large amounts of ice, because water is significantly more dense than air. This may be easier to comprehend if imagining an atmosphere of oil instead of air, and the boat floating at this boundary layer between two fluids.

Practically speaking, Ignoring evaporation and transpiration, the melting of an ice cube inside of a boat will not affect the waterline on the boat. The mass of the boat would stay the same, so the mass (and volume) of displaced water would stay the same.

The weight of the boat and whatever is on it doesn't change much when the ice melts. The surface in contact with water (i.e. the base of the boat) also remains constant.

However, if one considers evaporation, some amount of water would be lost into the atmosphere as the ice melts, thus decreasing the mass of boat and the boat might float slightly upwards. On the other hand, the water droplets dripping down will have some momentum, which would get transferred to the boat, moving it down ever so slightly. But to dig a bit deeper, the air surrounding us is a fluid. So, since the volume of ice is greater than that of water of the same mass, the ice would be facing higher buoyant force, which would mean that it would weigh less than liquid water of the same mass. Hence, when the ice melts, the boat would sink down by a tiny amount.

But overall, fore-mentioned factors will have a negligible effect. Hence, my original statement.

For the question about dripping water on a boat: I don't think so. On a boat the buoyant force (dependent on volume of sea-water displaced) balances the weight. Holy cow, the melting ice in a boat question is fascinating. The way I see it there are a few phases and variables to consider.

First, when the ice is completely solid, the mass of you and the mass of the ice are contributing to the overall mass of the boat. So let's suppose there is no bobbing at this time.

Now we get to the first drip. Once it drips, the moment it releases from the boat, there is less mass in the boat! So, in theory, it will experience an tiny acceleration due to the buoyant force being unbalanced, and it will rise. In practice I'm not sure what would happen since the droplet is so tiny the effect might be negligible. BUT if we take it to the extreme and imagine you're holding a boulder (this is a special boat that wont sink in imagination land) when it is released the boat will definitely respond and rise!

However! Once the droplet (or boulder if you like) lands again in the boat its mass is now accounted for again in the overall mass of the boat. But we're not done. It wont return to the original equilibrium position because a) the boat gained momentum during that interval where its mass was lessened and b) the droplet gained momentum while falling. So if the boat was initially completely at rest, it is now has some imparted momentum. (This isn't energy for free BTW, it came from the work gravity did on the droplet/boulder and the work buoyancy did on the boat) So at this moment, not only is it not at equilibrium, but it has some momentum. This means oscillation, and that means bobbing.

So we're done right? We can easily describe the motion now as a simple harmonic oscillator, right? Heck no. Not even close.

Another droplet will fall some time later, which depends on the heat exchange between your hand, the ice, and the environment. This will also change the droplet size (which is basically the mass change of the boat AND is proportional to the imparted momentum of the droplet). Furthermore, how tall are you? This will effect the imparted momentum as well. Higher height correlates to more momentum (not linearly though: it's related by the square root of the height). It will also change how long the droplet is subtracted from the mass of the boat. Also, what's the mass of the boat? That will affect the acceleration it experiences and therefore its change in momentum. Also, what is the shape of the boat? The buoyant force is proportional to the volume of water displaced, not the height. So the change in height will depend on the geometry of the boat. ALSO, are you in seawater or freshwater? This will effect the buoyancy force which is proportional to the density of the water, which in turn (you guessed it) will change the momentum of the boat.

All of this is just to say that thee most likely will be some very slight bobbing, but the exact nature of the bobbing is incredibly complex, dynamic, and dependent on quite a few parameters. It will very likely not be a simple sine wave.

Sorry for the very long response, and if you got this far, thanks for reading. ;)

As soon as the surface tension breaks, the drop is in free-fall and experiencing no force except wind resistance and critically, no upward force besides the nearly incalculably small gravitational force. This means the boat would rise up to compensate for the smaller normal force it has to provide to you. About the watermolecules from dinosaur pee... Water molecules constantly lose and gain hydrogen atoms. High school chemistry:
H₂O ⇌ OH⁻ + H₃O⁺
Which is basically hydrogen bonds being formed and the molecules arguing over whose hydrogen atom it was anyway when they inevitably divorce.

So it's kind of like Theseus ship. At what point is the water molecule no longer the same molecule? If it has replaced one of its hydrogen atoms? Both? Maybe we should just track the oxygen atoms then?

When water goes into a living cell, all kinds of weird stuff can happen. In photosynthesis the water is broken apart and used to build sugar molecules. But even in animal cells, the process used to burn those suger molecules for energy uses water to break the sugar into smaller parts. Parts of these water molecules become part of the new smaller molecules, while some of the hydrogen atoms are carried of in NADH; one of the energy carrying molecules in your body.

But even in the ocean, water can react with CO₂ from the air to form to form carbonic acid (which gives fizzy drinks a slightly acidic taste). Then, after some time the carbonic acid turns back into water and CO₂, but it might not be the same oxygen atom that turns back into water. Then there's weathering reactions that consume water molecules, polymerisation (usually in living things).

Are there any water molecules left from the time dinosaurs were peeing all over the Earth? Really depends on how you want to define a water molecule...

Great video! As the drop falls off the ice cube it's in free-fall and no longer being held up by the boat. So the boat will rise up a little bit in the water. Once it hits the bottom, the boat is supporting its weight once again, so it will go back down to its original level. The same will happen with the next drop. So the boat relative to the water will basically be alternating between two equilibrium positions. But because the water doesn't have that much damping the boat will actually oscillate around each equilibrium position-- overshoot it a bit, and then come back down a bit too far, but a little bit less on each cycle as energy dissipates.

Yes, the boat will go up and down as the ice melts. It will go:
a) DOWN as a bit of solid ice melts to liquid water (** see below).
b) UP as a drop of liquid water leaves your hand to fall towards the deck, as the boat becomes one drop lighter.
c) DOWN as the drop hits the deck, as the boat becomes one drop heavier again.
Effects (b) and (c) are transitory, and the boat will eventually end up at the same position it was after (a).

(**) When solid ice melts to liquid water, it takes up slightly LESS volume, so displaces slightly LESS atmospheric air. This results in slightly LESS buoyancy, and therefore slightly MORE total weight acting on the boat from the column of air above it. This effect will be truly minuscule, but real nonetheless.

Okay, I'm going to try to answer your water dripping on a boat question. My first thought was that the boat would not go up and down because the mass in the boat did not change, but then I thought a litter deeper about it. I love the way your videos make me do that! Here it goes. When a drop of water is hanging on to the ice cube, its mass is acting on the boat, but when the drop leaves the ice and starts its freefall to the deck, it is weightless and its mass is no longer acting on the boat, so the boat would rise a drops worth. When the drop hits the deck, its mass is once again acting on the boat and the boat would not only go back to its original position, but the energy being stored up in the drop from its freefall would, for a moment, make the boat drop lower and then rebound to its original position before the drop left the ice cube. How's that?

To fellow Canadian viewers: my favorite diffraction grating is the one found on dollar bills. There is a small somewhat transparent circle in the large maple leaf, that is a diffraction grating.
